awd_titl_txt: Stereocontrolled and Aerobic Oxidative Reactions at High-Valent Nickel Centers
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Dr. Liviu  Mirica of the Department of Chemistry at Washington University in St. Louis is investigating the role of nickel compounds in important chemical transformations. These include reactions that couple two different molecular partners ("cross-coupling") with improved selectivity, as well as  reactions related to the activation of inert organic substrates with oxygen. Cross-coupling reactions sped up by metal-containing compounds have become indispensable in the synthesis of a large number of important chemicals, pharmaceuticals, and materials. While palladium-based catalysts are the most commonly used, Dr. Mirica is synthesizing and studying nickel (Ni)-based catalysts as they may be able to react with a wider variety of target molecules and with more specificity.  In addition, Professor Mirica has established a collaboration with Professor Tim Hubin from Southwestern Oklahoma State University (SWOSU), a regional university in Oklahoma that has an appreciable amount of students that belong to underrepresented groups. Professor Hubin and his students collaborate on the synthesis of some of the targeted catalysts, visiting the Mirica lab, and performing reactivity studies using their chemical systems.  This experience exposes the undergraduate students to an R1 research institution, and inspires them to pursue advanced degrees in chemistry.  Professor Mirica and his group continue to work closely with collaborators from Spain and South Korea. This collaborative experience is an excellent training ground to prepare them to work in a true international environment, very similar to a multinational corporation.

While palladium (Pd)-based catalysts are arguably the most commonly used in cross-coupling reactions, Ni-based cross-coupling catalysts have been developed recently.  Given their ability to engage alkyl electrophiles and nucleophiles in stereospecific or stereoselective transformations the Ni-based catalysts are of interest. By comparison to the Pd-mediated transformations that generally employ diamagnetic intermediates, the Ni systems can more easily undergo one-electron redox reactions and lead to additional reaction pathways.  The presence of paramagnetic Ni(I) and Ni(III) species makes reactivity characterization more difficult. Dr. Mirica's laboratory is synthesizing isolated organometallic Ni(III) and Ni(IV) complexes supported by flexible multidentate ligands and studying in detail their involvement in important chemical transformations such as stereocontrolled C-C bond formation reactions and aerobic oxidative reactions mediated by high-valent Ni intermediates. This work has direct relevance to C-H functionalization and C-C / C-heteroatom bond formation reactions. Dr. Mirica is also recruiting graduate and undergraduate students from different backgrounds and providing them with an interdisciplinary training that spans inorganic, organic, and physical chemistry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this grant was to develop novel catalytic processes for stereocontrolled C-C bond formation reactions and aerobic oxidative reactions mediated by high-valent Ni intermediates, and the performed studies resulted in 11 publications, with 3 additional manuscripts being currently under review. During the previous funding period we have reported the isolation, detailed characterization, and reactivity studies of a series of organometallic mono-aryl/alkyl and di-alkyl/aryl NiIII and NiIV complexes supported by flexible multidentate ligands. More recently, we have isolated novel organometallic NiI complexes and have developed photocatalytic cross-coupling transformations, as well as established the conditions for selective oxidative C-C vs. C-O bond formation involving high-valent Ni species. During these studies we took advantage of our ability to judiciously design ligands that control the electronic properties and reactivity of metal ions in various oxidation states. In addition, we are specifically equipped to study both paramagnetic and diamagnetic systems by employing a series of spectroscopic, mechanistic, and computational approaches to characterize in detail the electronic properties and reactivity of these Ni systems. Finally, the performed studies have generated metal complexes with unique reactivity profiles and should lead to unique Ni-mediated oxidative transformations relevant to organic synthesis, which may impact how chemists put atoms together to build complex molecules more efficiently.

During this funding period, 4 graduate students, 3 undergraduate students, and one postdoctoral scholar have been involved in this project, of which 4 were female and 3 were part of underrepresented groups. All group members have received an interdisciplinary training that includes organometallic and inorganic synthesis, mechanistic studies, catalyst design, electrochemistry, and physical inorganic spectroscopy. In addition, all laboratory members have presented their results at least once per year at national or regional scientific meetings (e.g., Undergraduate Research Symposia, National or Regional ACS National Meetings, etc.), which are excellent opportunities to develop their presentation and communication skills.

In addition, the PI is actively involved in outreach efforts toward recruiting students from Predominantly Undergraduate Institutions with a diverse student body, involving them in research at the University of Illinois – an R1 research institution, and inspiring them to pursue advanced degrees in STEM. The PI considers it is extremely important to recruit graduate and undergraduate students from different backgrounds and providing them with an interdisciplinary training that spans inorganic, organic, and physical chemistry. Unfortunately, due to the COVID-19 pandemic we could not welcome any undergraduate students in our lab during the Summer and Fall 2020 semester, however starting in Spring/Summer 2021 and continuing during the entire 2021-2022 academic year we had three undergraduate students perform research in the lab.
